The COVID-19 pandemic is considered historical because very few of us today 81 were alive when the last pandemic of similar scale (the Spanish flu) plagued the world. It is 82 unprecedented because a pandemic in a globalized and interconnected world like the one we are 83 currently living in has never occurred before [7] . However, this pandemic was expected and 84 governments had prepared contingency plans. Nevertheless, Morse's paper expressed the concern 85 that "unless effective action against pandemic flu is taken now, we are in "dire straits,"" [8] . 86 Indeed, as immunization was the cornerstone of countries' strategy, with antiviral agents as a 87 backup, producing and distributing a vaccine was estimated to take at the very least 4 to 6 months. 88 The contingency plans therefore focused on nonpharmacological interventions, such as hand 89 washing, "respiratory etiquette," face masks, school closures, and social distancing or isolation. to declare a global pandemic [10] . The behavioural response to COVID-19 is unavoidably collective. Each person's chance 104 of contracting the virus depends not only on their own behaviour, but also on the behaviour of their 105 fellow citizens [12] . 106 This paper proposes to review the published literature on the successful leveraging of 107 behavioural insights during past epidemics and on the data available at time of writing on the 108 current pandemic. Whilst countries response worldwide was predominantly national, how global 109 leaders embraced the diversity of the behavioural insights specific to their own citizens to design 110 the landing page of their governmental institutions' website will be assessed. It will be shown that 111 far from expectations, the response to the sanitary crisis was very consensual with countries 112 implementing 80% of the behavioural insights observed. The research shows that beyond this 113 consensus, the individual and social nudges had no impact on the number of cases and deaths of 114 COVID-19 observed and instead it was the environmental interventions that had a significant 115 impact. What are the drivers that explain these results will be later discussed. 118 Understanding a global population's response to a worldwide pandemic such as COVID-19 is not 119 straightforward and requires rigorous analysis. Below are four putative applications of behavioural 120 science that are relevant to understanding this. 1. Behavioural science can not only be used as a 121 powerful tool to understand humans, 2. it is key to drafting impactful and targeted messages to 122 support crisis communication techniques and to ensure that what is conveyed is heard and 123 perceived as intended. 3. Behavioural science insights can help leverage the feeling of belonging 124 and 4. finally can be used to direct human behaviours toward outcomes [13] .

This paper sought to take a 686 snapshot at a specific time point of the behavioural nudges used by 33 governments on the landing 687 page of their official COVID-19 websites in order to attempt to understand the behavioural 688 response of a subset of the 7 billion individuals impacted by this pandemic. We showed that the 689 nudges were mostly unsuccessful irrespective of their framing and suggested that in order for them 690 to foster impact they should not only be more precise but importantly recursive. It is not enough manner. It is hoped that this paper will provide some insight on how to do so. 698 699 VII. FIGREF38.text: consensus was observed across all 33 countries552    What was observed is that there was a behavioural consensus across all 33 countries in the way 553 they handled the sanitary crisis. Further none of the countries used the behavioural insight of positive reinforcement 562 or reward giving [78]. 563 The majority (29 out of 33 countries), all provided information about the importance of 564 handwashing and provided a hotline help number, but two countries (Lithuania and Croatia) did 565 not provide help to support the coping of self-isolation through social networks, phone and video 566 calls or social media or provide a hotline access. Our results show that simply by using an environmental factor 579 mechanism on the landing pages of their official COVID-19 websites, governments could reduce 580 the spread of the disease and the number of cases. 581 These results demonstrate that irrespective of the framing of the behavioural insight 582 depending on the culture, the use of individual and social nudges has no impact. Additionally, the impact of a population taking some 590protective measures may be negative on others and wearing a mask could make people feel 591 sufficiently protected such that they don't make the effort to further wash their hands[83].
